action.action-desc: Mr. Latta (for himself, Mrs. Miller of Michigan, Mr. Quigley, and Ms. Kaptur) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce

form.official-title: To amend the Safe Drinking Water Act to provide for the assessment and management of the risk of cyanotoxins in drinking water, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Drinking Water Protection Act.

section.header: Amendment to the Safe Drinking Water Act

subsection.text: At the end of part E of the Safe Drinking Water Act (42 U.S.C. 300j et seq.) add the following new section:

paragraph.text: Not later than 90 days after the date of enactment of this section, the Administrator shall develop and submit to Congress a strategic plan for assessing and managing risks associated with cyanotoxins in drinking water provided by public water systems. The strategic plan shall include steps and timelines to—

subparagraph.text: evaluate the risk to human health from drinking water provided by public water systems contaminated with cyanotoxins;
establish, publish, and update a comprehensive list of cyanotoxins determined by the Administrator to be harmful to human health when present in drinking water provided by public water systems;

clause.text: the known adverse human health effects of cyanotoxins included on the list published under subparagraph (B) when present in drinking water provided by public water systems; and
factors that cause cyanobacteria to proliferate and express toxins;

subparagraph.text: with respect to cyanotoxins included on the list published under subparagraph (B), determine whether to—

clause.text: publish health advisories pursuant to section 1412(b)(1)(F) for such cyanotoxins in drinking water provided by public water systems;
establish guidance regarding feasible analytical methods to quantify the presence of cyanotoxins; and
establish guidance regarding the frequency of monitoring necessary to determine if such cyanotoxins are present in drinking water provided by public water systems;

subparagraph.text: recommend feasible treatment options, including procedures and equipment, to mitigate any adverse public health effects of cyanotoxins included on the list published under subparagraph (B); and

enter into cooperative agreements with, and provide technical assistance to, affected States and public water systems, as identified by the Administrator, for the purpose of managing risks associated with cyanotoxins included on the list published under subparagraph (B).

paragraph.text: The Administrator shall, as appropriate, update and submit to Congress the strategic plan developed under paragraph (1).

subsection.text: In carrying out this section the Administrator shall—

paragraph.text: identify gaps in the Agency’s understanding of cyanobacteria, including—

subparagraph.text: the human health effects of cyanotoxins included on the list published under subsection (a)(1)(B); and
methods and means of testing and monitoring for the presence of harmful cyanotoxins in source water of, or drinking water provided by, public water systems;

clause.text: address public health concerns related to harmful algal blooms;

paragraph.text: assemble and publish information from each Federal agency that has—

subparagraph.text: addressed public health concerns related to harmful algal blooms.

subsection.text: The Administrator shall carry out this section in accordance with the requirements described in section 1412(b)(3)(A), as applicable.
For purposes of this section, the term feasible has the meaning given such term in section 1412(b)(4)(D).
Not later than 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General of the United States shall prepare and submit to Congress a report that includes—

subparagraph.text: expended by the United States, for each of fiscal years 2010 through 2014, to examine or analyze cyanobacteria or address public health concerns related to harmful algal blooms; and
that includes the specific purpose for which the funds were made available, the law under which the funds were authorized, and the Federal agency that received or spent the funds; and

paragraph.text: recommended steps to reduce any duplication, and improve interagency coordination, of such expenditures.
